charts.description: What is the average level of VAT for components needed to build a wind project?
What is the average level of import duties for components needed for a solar project (panels and inverts)?

sectionCopy.name: Clean energy policy
sectionCopy.value: Tunisia aims to move toward a cleaner power matrix and jump from 3% of renewables generation in 2016 to 12% in 2020, rising to 30% by 2030. Two separate auction regimes (authorization for smaller projects and concession for larger projects) are the main instruments to achieve the objectives. Under the authorization regime, the government contracted in 2017 64MW of PV capacity and aims to contract 200MW more in December 2018. Under the concession regime, Tunisia announced in 2018 that it will contract 1GW equally split between wind and solar plants. Project deadlines vary between 1H 2021 and end-2022 and the winners will secure a 20-year PPA with the state-owned utility STEG. In addition, retail electricity consumers in Tunisia who have renewable energy facilities can connect and deliver surplus generation to the grid, in return for payment from STEG.

sectionCopy.name: Clean energy investment
sectionCopy.value: Tunisia has received little investment in utility-scale clean energy so far, but that is poised to change as over 1GW of auction-winning projects are expected to be commissioned by end-2022. International development banks have been the main debt providers for Tunisia's clean energy plants. The country’s Fond de Transicion Energetique (FTE) will invest 2.13 billion Tunisian dinars ($730 million) in energy transition projects over the next decade. The budget has grown significantly, from 1.3 billion Tunisian dinars between 2006 and 2015.

sectionCopy.name: Power prices and LCOEs
sectionCopy.value: Due to the high level of subsidies, Tunisia’s average residential electricity prices were among the 10 lowest in Africa at $52.5/MWh in 2017. Industrial and commercial prices – at $76/MWh and $87/MWh, respectively – are significantly higher than the residential tariff but still over 50% below the regional average.

sectionCopy.name: Power market
sectionCopy.value: Over 94% of Tunisia’s 5.5GW of installed capacity and more than 97% of the power produced in 2017 came from gas-fired plants. As of end-2017, only 240MW of wind plants and 62MW of small hydro were commissioned. However, the power mix is due to become more diversified over the next four years as auctions are due to increase the clean energy capacity. The state-owned utility Tunisia Company of Electricity and Gas (STEG) controls over 80% of power generation and has a monopoly over transmission and distribution of electricity and natural gas. IPPs are allowed in the market under the concession and authorization programs and can rely on a 20-year standardized PPA with STEG. According to law 2015-12 that regulates renewable energy generation, STEG is mandated to buy all power produced by clean energy plants.

sectionCopy.name: Doing business
sectionCopy.value: The country is slowly recovering from an economic crisis and reached 2% GDP growth in 2017, against 1.1% in 2016. The economy is forecasted to further expand with 2.5% GDP growth in 2018. After a 6% drop from 2015 to 2016, Tunisia’s peak power demand is recovering and recorded a spike of 18% year-on-year to 4,025MW in 2017. This represented the greatest increase since at least 2011. It is one of few countries in Africa with nearly 100% electrification rates.

sectionCopy.name: Barriers
sectionCopy.value: Uncertainties around political instability and relatively recent law (2015) that allowed IPPs in the market are the main barriers for international investors. This indicates that support from development organizations in form of concessional finance might be required to change the market risk perception. Tunisia has a 0% import tax for wind and solar products from the EU and 30% for products from outside of the EU. The country also imposes a 19% VAT on wind turbines, towers, blades and PV panels, and 7% for inverters.
